pageContext.description:
Bust-length portrait of the reformer Martin Luther. His head is turned slightly to the right, but he gazes straight out of the painting. The background is brown. 
[Rosgartenmuseum Konstanz, revised 2018]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 33.4 x 27.3 x 0.7 - 0.9 cm
[KKL 2020]
Dimensions including frame: 50 x 44.5 x 4.5 cm
[Rosgartenmuseum Konstanz, revised 2018]

involvedPersons.remarks:
'Eine der zahlreichen Kopien oder Werkstattversionen nach dem Bildnis von 1528'
[Rosgartenmuseum Konstanz, revised 2018]
involvedPersons.suffix: Copy after Lucas Cranach the Elder

pageContext.markings:
Verso: in brown ink: 'HHolbein pinxi(t) 1536'; somewhat further down: 'Lucas Cranach'. The lower inscription may have been added by Castell.
[Rosgartenmuseum Konstanz, revised 2018]

metadata.title: Portrait of Martin Luther

pageContext.provenance:
- from the Castell Collection? [see Cat. No.1.13]
- old Leiner-Inv. 1882, No. 161
[Rosgartenmuseum Konstanz, revised 2018]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
- good condition 
recto: the black paint has sunk (black robe and black beret, Luther is barely distinguishable from the blackish green background), dent in the chin and the collar, scratch (before the paint application?) across the upper lip.
verso: some woodworm damage visible, scratches, top left corner broken off, abrasion at the centre where the inscription is located  
[Rosgartenmuseum Konstanz, revised 2018]

tests.text:
- beech wood
- original tool marks visible, no fibre 
- not cropped, from one tangential board, vertical direction of the grain, 9 mm thick, not warped 
- marks from a mounting system (centred)

- thin, white ground (slightly visible along the edges) 
- barbe visible along the bottom edge (only slightly visible at the top and right edges) (c. 10 mm)
- the paint layers do not exhibit a barbe

- the underdrawing in the face is visible to the naked eye through the paint layers: facial features are indicated, the wrinkles on the forehead are emphasized and long bold strokes define the hair 

- free hand execution with no evidence of pounced dots (infrared reflectography) 

- for a comparison with underdrawings found on other portrait of Luther in other  museums see Cat. Rosgartenmuseum 1993, p. 74.

- the face exhibits very fine brush strokes, also employed in areas of shadow 
- no gilding

- old frame, but not original 
[Rosgartenmuseum Konstanz, revised 2018]

DESCRIPTION 

 Tools/Material:
 - dry, black drawing material, stylus 



Type/Ductus:
 - traced or copied underdrawing

- thin lines 




Function:
 - binding for the final painted version; lines delineate the main contours and describe essential details and facial features; only isolated representation of volume with hatching strokes 

Deviations:
 - almost no corrections were made to forms during the painting process

 INTERPRETATION

 Attribution: 
- not possible

Comments:

- probably transferred from a pre-existing design 

[Sandner, Smith-Contini, Heydenreich, cda 2019]
